column1: Before 1 January 2023, will China and/or a host country officially announce an agreement for the establishment of a Chinese military base in an African country besides Djibouti?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Security and Conflict', 'Non-US Politics']

I just came across a previous question somewhere about Chinese forces failing to show up at a Djibouti border conflict once. That to me signals a lack of interest or will to defend / take ownership of Djibouti in the near future.
Not looking likely at this point with China's focus on their big conference and not much time left in 2022.
Reducing forecast with the passage of time.
Time is running out, and China is busy with other things. I had thought that this would be very likely, but it hasn't happened yet, and there's not much time left.
As more time passes, there seems to be no news suggesting it's imminent.
Reducing for passage of time.

I believe that more likely than not, the PRC will establish the agreement for a military base outside of Djibouti. The PRC has been laying the groundwork for this for several years, and their recent actions indebting African countries to them (especially Zimbabwe) indicates that they are most likely reaching the grounds to make such an agreement now or in the very near future. Especially with focus on Ukraine and their aggression regarding Taiwan, it is likely that such an agreement would not garner much public attention. This would probably be to the liking of the PRC, as they have kept their developments in Africa, even their base in Djibouti, out of the limelight as well. This seems to be the perfect time for such an agreement to be established, and it would also appear that the PRC has the means to do so.

I'm wondering whether there could potentially be an announcement in the relatively near future, because there has been a huge uptick in twitter bot accounts tweeting about how the US has 800 military bases around the world and China has only 1. Maintaining my forecast.https://twitter.com/search?q=china%20military%20base&src=typed_query

Absent news, I'm now adopting a -5% per month passage-of-time decay rate.
I do think it's likely, but I'm going to hedge my bets for the moment.

If somebody could compare — EDIT: of course, not you — the many sources of current and latest available sat images from - Bata (#1) 1.832001 9.739895 (赤道几内亚 巴塔 港 chi-dao ji-nei-ya bata gang = Equatorial Guinea Bata Port, GQ BSG BATA)- Bata (#2) 1.806908 9.741987against the reference Chinese naval base- Djibouti 11.590230 43.063120 https://eos.com/blog/free-satellite-imagery-sources/we could figure out, whether or not.---Opinion: I've used BING's sat images and cannot figure out the date of the current image, it looks like there is construction behind Bata #2; if Bata #1 would hold a naval base of the size of Djibouti's naval base, it would flatten out substantial areas where no settlements exists and then build a very long jetty into the sea and lots of buildings. So, this suggests South of Bata #2 (1.806908 9.741987) because the North is full of civilians. They wouldn't pick a civilian area for a mil installation, yet won't move too far away. Djibouti's is as large as the current civilian port of Bata #1; in other words, if the civilian port remains, another such massive installation would be needed.I also used https://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/ with 1km radius circle to compare the sites. USGS looks like BING.By the way, you can use 赤道几内亚 巴塔 港 to search for Chinese pages or images.Opinion 2: There is a lot of banter. Since the Chinese can build faster and larger than Tesla, and last time the first reports appeared one year ahead of the finalization, I would expect actual evidence rather than rumors about talks. As of May 2022, I've only found rumors.
I probably should start cutting this for passage of time, but I'll wait a bit on that.

Maintaining forecast. China is apparently trying to establish a military base anywhere on the Atlantic coast of Africa and "has placed bets or chips down on... almost all the countries along the Atlantic coast." See from about 7:30 in this VOA interview with US AFRICOM commander Gen. Townsend, posted March 17: https://www.voanews.com/a/voa-interview-africom-s-general-stephen-townsend/6490059.html Starting at about 7:30 for discussion about the western coast of Africa: Equatorial Guinea is where they have gotten "the most traction." The leaders of Equatorial Guinea have assured the US that they are not going to say yes to China about a military base, but the US is watching closely. From about 8:53 onward for the eastern coast: no real traction. But, returning to the western coast, China has also been interested in Gabon, but so far, Gabon has said no. From 10:23 for a discussion of Somalia: China has been interested in Somalia, but so far, Somalia has told the US that they intend to say no. "We'll leave it at that for now."

Maintaining forecast. "The Chinese are activity seeking a military naval base in Africa on the Atlantic coast, which would threaten U.S. national security, Army Gen. Stephen J. Townsend, commander of U.S. Africa Command said. ... "The thing I think I'm most worried about is this military base on the Atlantic coast, and where they have the most traction for that today is in Equatorial Guinea," Townsend said.

Maintaining forecast. "Equatorial Guinea’s New Cooperation Agreement with China Could be Sending a Message: Equatorial Guinea and China signed an agreement on Tuesday to promote development cooperation between the two countries." https://chinaafricaproject.com/2022/03/02/equatorial-guineas-new-cooperation-agreement-with-china-could-be-sending-a-message
Dropped to the lower side of 5050 Potentially they will work towards a network of alliances or 'string of pearls' rather than actually having their own bases.
Some time has passed, and if anything China will be more focused on seeing whether reactions to Ukraine give it a window of opportunity in Taiwan.
with a growing number of assets to look after, China will gradually expand to Africa
If things are hard for the US re: Russia but not too hard - America comes out of that 'limping' than yes China will likely do something like this.

"Townsend, who took over U.S. Africa Command in 2019, also said that China is the "most active" of America’s global competitors in Africa and is "intent on building a military air base and/or naval facility in Equatorial Guinea." "We're not asking them (Equitorial Guinea) to choose between China and us. What we're asking them to do is consider their other international partners and their concerns, because a Chinese military base in Equatorial Guinea is of great concern to the U.S. and all of their other partners," Townsend said." https://www.voanews.com/a/voa-exclusive-us-africom-commander-says-russian-mercenaries-in-mali/6406371.html

With China having an increased issue with their zero COVID policies, tensions with US and Taiwan concerning their regional ambitions, and their sometimes questionable appeal as an economic partner to countries in the BRI; I do not feel that 2022 will be a year in which China would risk investing in an African military base.

Anybody know why it would be better for Equatorial Guinea to announce such a plan publicly? Also, what is the influence of China having a bias toward African countries because of the potential for new variants or simply for the Omicron variant to catch a ride into Chinese blood? It seems China cares deeply about keeping its COVID numbers low. Hovering 20% for now until I can get passed these questions of mine.

Just repeating my forecast to note that some rumors are also circulating about China potentially building a military base in Zimbabwe. People are also noticing that the Chinese foreign minister's visits to Africa this year include Eritrea, Kenya and the Comoros, leading to at least a small amount of speculation that China might be interested in setting up a base in Eritrea. https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3161852/chinese-foreign-minister-set-3-nation-tour-east-africa-beijing At this point, these are rumors only, so far as I can tell.

Ongoing negotiations musn't count. But why would this matter be announced like the world has to know? China has been building bases and islands in the South China Sea without announcing anything by and large, as the world watched. Why am I wrong here? Are there formal negotiations currently known of besides speculation?

Equatorial Guinea looks like a good bet at the moment. It has the charm of a hopelessly corrupt government, a territory small enough to control or at least monitor easily, and a location on the US side of Africa. The plan is to pretend it's to act against piracy in the Gulf of Guinea. Stay tuned.

"Gargash confirmed reports that the UAE -- a key regional US ally -- had shuttered a Chinese facility over US allegations that the site was being used as a military base. He made clear that Abu Dhabi was merely paying lip service to US intelligence -- the UAE didn't actually agree with Washington's characterization of the site. Abu Dhabi simply did not want to upset a strategic ally." "Analysts argue that if Washington forces the region to choose between the US and China, the answer will be a no-brainer -- the US' friends in the region are loath to draw the ire of the superpower, especially while its military presence in the Middle East remains expansive. But ultimately, the region may have no choice but to take the Chinese carrot even if it means subjecting itself to the American stick." "The main weakness in the US' proposition regarding China in the Middle East is that Washington offers no alternatives to Beijing's lucrative deals." https://www.cnn.com/2021/12/27/middleeast/china-middle-east-uae-analysis-cmd-intl/index.html

Yes: Singleton seemed to mention that China is building a military base in Tanzania. China also seemed to suggest it is completely normal to continue building more military bases overseas. Uncertainties: 1. Relationship between China and African countries might cool down due to unsatisfactory investment returns and debt issues 2. How important is Tanzania in terms of geography? 3. China’s own debt crisis may hold back its investments overseas & military expenses To verify: 1. Geopolitically important African countries (where the US / UK / France has built bases in) 2. China’s relationship with African countries.

It appears Guinea (along with Mali and Ethiopia) is about to lose its eligibility status as "beneficiary country" for the U.S. AGOA trade and development program. This time, it could be gone for good imho, and it could be connected to alienation between former partners and to increasingly close ties with the PRC. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_Growth_and_Opportunity_Act#Eligibility https://ustr.gov/issue-areas/trade-development/preference-programs/african-growth-and-opportunity-act-agoa
Okay, a base for dealing with pirates in the Gulf of Guinea ( @SE_Meyer ) actually is a plausible reason for China to want a naval base in Equatorial Guinea.

"By 2021, Equatorial Guinea’s debt to China amounted to an estimated 49.7 per cent of GDP." "Equatorial Guinea presented China with an opportunity to establish a military presence on the Atlantic. But the country’s government is not alone among African nations with a high indebtedness to China and in which Beijing plays a central economic development role. It is possible that other Chinese naval bases may yet appear on Africa’s Atlantic coast. Whether or not it builds such new installations in the short term, Beijing’s consolidation of a pan-African security architecture will undoubtedly lead to their establishment in the long term." https://ecfr.eu/article/chinas-new-military-base-in-africa-what-it-means-for-europe-and-america/

Thanks to @see and @srwade9 for links to articles about how China wants to have a military base in Equatorial Guinea, and for great analysis. I wonder how long it would take for an agreement to be reached with China, if one is eventually reached.

I am raising my forecast to a 1 in 2 chance of this happening before 1 Jan 2023 given recent reporting from the WSJ: "Classified American intelligence reports suggest China intends to establish its first permanent military presence on the Atlantic Ocean in the tiny Central African country of Equatorial Guinea, according to U.S. officials. (https://www.wsj.com/articles/china-seeks-first-military-base-on-africas-atlantic-coast-u-s-intelligence-finds-11638726327?mod=hp_lead_pos9) U.S. officials are visiting Equatorial Guinea (EG) in classic react mode trying to persuade them to not accept Beijing's proposal. At this point, EG is in the cat bird seat and could use the situation to gain a better deal or arrangement with either China or the U.S. It will come down to who is the most persuasive and can help address EG their issues and bring a long-term boost their economy.

Okay, I'm pushing up on reports that there's supposedly plans for a base in Equatorial Guinea (complete with the US sending diplomats to try to head it off), even though nobody has given any good explanation as to why China would want a base there.
Peoples Liberation Army Navy (PLAN) will announce an Army base in Equatorial Guinea and a Naval base in Tanzania.
they do not need a base to achieve what they want not woth the risk to their desire to be considered a responsible world leader for china
They will do things, but not officially announce them. Not in their interest.
China has increasing links with African states.
They really can't back out of Africa now.

I am going to give this about a 1 in 4 chance. First, overall, China is involved in 46 port projects in sub-Saharan Africa alone, not even counting the more strategically important North Africa/Mediterranean region. If you look at maps of China's maritime silk road, in addition to Djibouti, it shows access at and supported by a port in Kenya (https://www.futuredirections.org.au/publication/making-sense-of-five-years-of-chinas-belt-and-road-initiative/). As well and though not perfect, China and Kenya have had relatively warm relations for several decades. (https://allafrica.com/stories/201405090309.html#:~:text=The%2050-year%20bilateral%20relations%20between%20Kenya%20and%20China,fourth%20country%20to%20open%20an%20embassy%20in%20Nairobi) There are numerous reports about China and Kenya deepening their economic ties (https://newsaf.cgtn.com/news/2021-10-12/Wang-Yi-holds-telephone-conversation-with-Kenyan-counterpart-14hHHYyikbS/index.html; https://www.oxfordhandbooks.com/view/10.1093/oxfordhb/9780198815693.001.0001/oxfordhb-9780198815693-e-42) So Kenya is one key possibility and would give them greater presence in the Western Indian Ocean. Another real possibility is in Tangier, Morocco. "The Chinese presence in Morocco and Egypt, meanwhile, is concentrated in industrial zones, free trade zones, and financial centers. In Morocco, these include the Atlantic Free Zone in Kenitra, Casablanca Finance City (CFC), and the Tanger Med Port Complex. At the latter port complex, Chinese companies, including telecommunications giant Huawei, are planning to establish regional logistics centers." (https://www.brookings.edu/research/beijing-calling-assessing-chinas-growing-footprint-in-north-africa/) PLAN presence in Tangiers would permit China to monitor everything coming and going through the Strait of Gibraltar and a strong economic foothold in Western Africa. "Other initiatives include a $10 billion Chinese-funded industrial city in Tangier, which would give Beijing a technological hub next to one of the continent’s most dynamic ports." (https://thediplomat.com/2019/07/china-has-quietly-carved-out-a-foothold-in-north-africa/)

Okay, to start with, I highly doubt China is actually considering a naval base on the Atlantic coast of Africa, as suggested in the AP article. That would be bizarrely provocative given how basically useless it would be for any rational Chinese interest. If China were looking for a base to "send a message", one in Cuba, Venezuela, or Syria would send a much louder one.
They won't announce it.

There are few public reports of on-going discussions about particular locations. Few countries would want a public announcement even if they did host PRC military forces. It's a particularly sensitive topic now, and a public announcement would likely draw a rebuke from the US and maybe bring public press. So the probably is pretty low. But not nonexistent, as there are reasons some countries might both want a base and be willing to announce it.
Djibouti is uniquely strategically important + no new African bases in 5 years + China has a lot of foreign entanglements it is interested in starting or resolving closer to home

Looks like China is focussing more these days on power and their armed forces. With the 5 year convention next year getting an announcement on an overseas projection of that power might be something in the agenda.

As links through BRI initiatives grow particularly in countries within the African continent, there is an increased likelihood of stronger state relations which could allow for another Chinese military base in Africa. Something that could stop this would be public opinion or discontent with Chinese initiatives.

with CCP-Leadership likely unclear until late 2022, I would expect african countries to wait and bargain for substantial commitments until then. If no change in leadership, then demonstrations of consolidation of domestic power are likely first, so I would suspect such announcements not until after closing this question. If change in leadership, not opening new bases might be used as bargaining chip for re-integration of supply-chains, with same result.

China already has negotiated capacity for its Djibouti base to host an aircraft carrier. It's nice to have redundancy on a single coast, but when it's your first base far from home, ensuring that one is squared away probably takes priority over negotiating a second one. And for China, diversity of regional influence may be far preferable. There is also the UAE - not technically in Africa, but somewhat in the same region - with whom China has larger trade and whose geography enables a new node of access to the Persian gulf. The Economist's Intelligence Unit predicts UAE will be relatively politically stable in the 2022-26 period. UAE/PRC relations have warmed through a "comprehensive strategic partnership". With regards to the Mid-East more broadly relative to Africa, NDU published in early 2020 that "Beyond Asia, it is clear that the PLA’s initial area of focus is securing the SLOCs [Strategic Sea Lines of Communication] from the Middle East through the Indian Ocean that provide the majority of China’s energy imports and maritime commerce".

If it's about protecting Chinese interests then "The top 5 African destinations of Chinese FDI in 2019 were Democratic Republic of Congo, Angola, Ethiopia, South Africa, and Mauritius." http://www.sais-cari.org/chinese-investment-in-africa
American and european vacuum, and the new silk belt and road agreements make it a pretty sure bet .
